p: Anapathur V. Ramesh received the B. Tech degree in civil engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), the M. S. and Ph. D. degrees in structural engineering from Duke University, and the M. S. degree in computer science from Duke University.
Since 1997 he has been with Boeing Commercial Airplane Group working in areas of reliability analysis techniques, durability analysis, and reliability data analysis.
David W. Twigg received the B. Sc. degree in electrical engineering from the University of California at Berkeley, and the M. Sc. degree in mathematics from the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
He has been with Boeing since 1965, where he has developed software and algorithms for solving engineering problems.

Upender R. Sandadi received the B.E. (1991) degree in electronics and communication engineering from Osmania University, India, and the M. S. (1993) degree in electrical engineering from the University of Washington.
From 1994 to 1999 he was with the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group as a reliability engineer performing reliability modeling and performance-evaluation of fault-tolerant systems.

Tilak C. Sharma received the B. Sc. (Honors) and M. Sc. degrees from Punjab University in India, the M. S. degree from the University of Denver, the Ph. D. degree from the University of Alberta, Canada, and the M.B.A. from the Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville.

He is a Technical Fellow of The Boeing Company and a leading researcher in advanced reliability techniques, and is involved in assuring consideration of reliability and maintainability in the design of critical systems.

details.abstract: This paper considers the reliability analysis of systems whose operation time is managed with regard to criticality of faults. Several analysis approaches are proposed for the numerical probability analysis of one such operational scenario: FOTM (flight operation time management). The equations derived for the Markov chain based method are novel and their implementation in the tool SPNP (Stochastic Petri Net Program) could help in assessing the risk reduction due to FOTM. The analysis methods are quite general and can be applied to other similar situations where system-failure risk is decreased by operation-time management.

context.text: CTMC [9], [11], [16] are very versatile in representing failure behavior in systems.

Thus there are Time-Inhomogeneous CTMC where the state-transition probabilities depend on global time, and Time-Homogeneous CTMC where the state transition probabilities depend only on elapsed time [11].

For example, the FAA has a requirement that catastrophic failure conditions in airplane systems be shown to be extremely improbable with an average failure rate no more than 10−9/flight-hour [12], [13].

context.text: A notable previous contribution in numerical probability analysis of airplane systems under operation-time management is [15].

While [15] considers the specific problem of engine failures, the methods and the equations in this paper apply to other systems that can be quite complex such as a typical airplane electrical system.
Reference [15] uses a diversion distance that is a function of the airplane location in flight as opposed to a diversion-time function.
